Birth of an Empire Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street; (212) 535-7710.

''Art and the Empire City: New York, 1825-61,'' an exhibition exploring the growth of New York as the center of culture, art and architecture in the United States between the opening of the Erie Canal and the start of the Civil War, starts on Tuesday and continues through Jan. 7.
The exhibition will include 310 works, among them a rosewood armchair and nested tables made by Duncan Phyfe and an 1861 seed-pearl necklace with matching bracelets worn by Mary Todd Lincoln.

There will also be architectural drawings and lithographs, and paintings like ''View of the Round-Top in the Catskill Mountains'' by Thomas Cole (1827) and ''New York Harbor'' by Fitz Hugh Lane (1850), along with two presentation boards for the proposed Central Park by Frederick Law Olmsted.
Open Tuesday through Sunday, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. (Friday and Saturday until 9 p.m.). Suggested admission is $10; students and those 65 and older, $5.
A Walk in Brooklyn P.S. 9 Annex, corner of Sterling Place and Vanderbilt Avenue, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; (718) 707-1277.
A self-guided walking tour to six houses and St. Joseph's Church, a building in Italian Renaissance style, will take place on Sunday from 1 to 5 p.m. Tickets are $15.
An Innovative Designer Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street; (212) 217-5800.

An exhibition of clothing, photographs and personal memorabilia of the designer Bonnie Cashin, who died in February, opens on Tuesday and runs through Jan. 6. Ms. Cashin designed costumes for ''Anna and the King of Siam'' (1946), ''Laura'' and other plays and films.

In 1953, she started her own design company in New York. Her ideas for an active woman's wardrobe included layering, unstructured silhouettes and practical innovations like jackets with detachable purses, in place of pockets, and sweaters with funnel necks to double as hoods. Open Tuesday through Friday, noon to 8 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free.
Garden Fair Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue (Eastern Parkway), Prospect Heights; (718) 623-7200.

A harvest fair with horticultural contests and exhibits, canning demonstrations and activities for children, will take place on Saturday, from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Admission to the garden is $3; those 65 and older, $1.50. Admission is free with a donation of a food can, to be given to City Harvest.
Digital Design Great Hall at Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street; (212) 353-4214.
John Maeda, a professor of design and computation at the M.I.T. Media Laboratory, will speak about digital media on Tuesday at 6 p.m. Free.
Newark Architecture Information Booth at Pennsylvania Station, Raymond Blvd. West off McCarter Highway, Newark; (973) 733-4870.
A guided walking tour, on Sunday from 1:45 to 4 p.m., will include the 1890 First Baptist Peddie Memorial Church, Washington Park and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. The fee is a $1 donation.
